page.title: 09FARMING - 3
page.content: {Evenlode Grounds:}The 80 hectares of permanent wet grassland at Evenlode Grounds has been owned and farmed by the same family for 200 years. Much of this managed grassland is ridge and furrow. Clay from the 'Brick Field' was used to make the bricks to build the farmhouse. A Friesian dairy herd store cattle, and some sheep, are fed in winter on home-made silage and hay with bought 'dairy nuts'. Manure is spread on the grass. The family run the farm with some casual help. Contractors cut the hedges. There is a computerised milking parlour. Milk tankers take the milk to Kidlington, near Oxford, Stock goes to Banbury market or is sold on the farm to dealers. Paddocks in other villages are rented for grass keep for the stock.
